text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. This is a short but fun video about

laughter how often do you laugh? They say that 
people who laugh a lot from the heart live happier

lives. Laughter is a form of stress relief. Of 
course, cruel laughter isn't good for anyone,
so surround yourself with healthy forms of humor.

A joke that's a little funny, but not 
terribly funny might make me chuckle.

That's a low, quiet laugh 
often with our mouth closed.
If I'm feeling silly, I might giggle.

Giggling is quick and high pitched. It's a 
series of laughs. People of all ages might

giggle when they feel nervous, so it's 
not always a positive form of laughter.

Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. In this lesson, we're going to talk

about inversion. Do you know what it means 
to invert something? I'll give you a hint.
What did I do with the hourglass? I inverted it.

When you invert the hourglass, the 
sand pours down into the bottom part.
How about this photo? Can you see it properly?

Probably not. Let me invert it. I'll rotate it 
and put it right side up. Now can you see it?

In grammar, if we invert two parts of a 
sentence, we reverse their positions. You

already know how to do this. We invert the 
subject and verb when we form questions.
Have you ever seen such clear blue water?

Yes, I have. I've seen 
beautiful water in the Bahamas.

We can also invert the subject and verb 
in sentences that use negative adverbs.

We do this when the negative 
adverb is in the initial position.

That means it starts the sentence. We 
don't usually do this in spoken English.

It's more typical of written English because it's 
a more formal structure, so you can expect to see

inversion with negative adverbs more in 
academic writing and literary writing.

Let's practice together. Look at this 
sentence. First, identify the negative adverb.

Never. Right? We'll move it to the beginning of 
the sentence. Next, we'll switch...we'll invert

the subject and verb. Only the first part of 
the verb. We'll use the helping verb first.

So, what's the new sentence? Never have 
I seen such clear, beautiful water.

Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer 
from English with Jennifer.

How comfortable are you 
saying long words in English?

Well, in this video, I'll help you say and 
use at least one of those words: comfortable.

In everyday American English, we 
say this word with three syllables:

comfortable. Stress is on the first: comfortable. 
It sounds like I'm saying "kumf ter bull."

Let's say it again. We'll say it 
slowly and then fast. Comfortable.
Comfortable.

You may hear some American English 
speakers say this word with four syllables:

comfortable. Comfortable. But I think 
this variation is a little less common.

Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer. You may know that I've played a

lot of card games in my life. I grew up playing 
popular games like Blackjack, Slapjack, Go Fish,

and some less common games like Steal the Pile and 
500. I hope that card games don't die out because

of video games and entertainment apps. There 
are a lot of idioms related to playing cards,

and they sure make a lot more sense 
if you've actually played these games.
In this lesson, I'll share four expressions.

"To play your cards right" means to do 
things in the best way possible in order

to be successful and get what you want or 
get something of value. We often use this

in an IF-clause. If you play your cards right, 
you might get a promotion in one or two years.

He's a good athlete, and he could get a 
scholarship if he plays his cards right.

Hi everyone. It's Jennifer from English with 
Jennifer, and I'm outside in front of my home.

I live in the suburbs, and this is pretty typical 
for a suburban home. We have a mailbox at the end

of our driveway. This is where we get and 
send our mail. If I want to mail a letter,

I put it in the mailbox and I put up this flag to 
signal the mail carrier to stop. She usually stops

anyways because we get a few letters every day. 
If I want to send a bigger envelope or a package,

I have to go to the post office. Now some 
people like to decorate their mailboxes

for the different seasons or a special holiday. 
I decorate the mailbox just for Christmas.

Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English 
with Jennifer. It won't surprise you

to know that I believe everyone should 
know at least a little bit of grammar.

Grammar is all about patterns, and following the 
usual patterns helps us have clear communication.
What's the difference between a word and a phrase?

A word is a single piece of language: cat, 
girl, sing, singing, beautiful, beautifully,

to, from, here. A phrase is a group of 
two or more words: a beautiful girl,
sing beautifully, for me.

Phrases aren't complete ideas. They 
don't have both a subject and a verb.

Sometimes we speak in phrases if the rest is 
understood. What do you see? A pretty cat.

A clause is a group of words with a subject 
and a verb. Clauses can be short or long.
The girl sang.

Songs entertain us. Birds are common 
pets in many countries around the world.
Inside a clause, you may find a number of phrases.

Some clauses can stand alone. We 
call them independent clauses. An

independent clause is a simple sentence. 
Other clauses are dependent clauses.

We have to join these dependent clauses with an 
independent clause to form a complete sentence.

If you don't know what to do 
with this, I can show you.

Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer 
from English with Jennifer.

Try saying "toy boat" five times fast: toy 
boat, toy boat, toy boat...It's not easy, is it?

But if I slow down, I can do it. Toy boat, 
toy boat, toy boat, toy boat, toy boat. Tongue

twisters can be short or long, but they're 
all designed to twist our tongue. We can

untwist it and speak clearly if we slow down just 
enough to stay in control of our pronunciation.
Follow me on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram.
